Package infodynamics.measures.spiking

Interface TransferEntropyCalculatorSpiking

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorSpikingIntegration
    public interface TransferEntropyCalculatorSpiking

    Interface for implementations of the transfer entropy (TE), which may be applied to spiking time-series data. That is, it is applied to double[] data, as an array of time stamps at which spikes were recorded. See Schreiber below for the definition of transfer entropy, and Lizier et al. for the definition of local transfer entropy, and (To be published) for how to measure transfer entropy on spike trains. Specifically, this class implements the pairwise or apparent transfer entropy; i.e. we compute the transfer that appears to come from a single source variable, without examining any other potential sources (see Lizier et al, PRE, 2008).

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String) e.g. including properties describing the source and destination embedding;
    3. Initialise the calculator using initialise() or initialise(int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • setObservations(double[], double[]) for calculations based on single recordings, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to addObservations(double[], double[]), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average TE: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local TE values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • the distribution of TE values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: #computeSignificance(int) or #computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • To be published
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

        Parameters:

                int l)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for re-use with new observations. New history embedding lengths k and l can be supplied here; all other parameters remain unchanged.
        Parameters:
        k - destination history embedding length to be considered.
        l - source history embedding length to be considered.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                 java.lang.String propertyValue)
          throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • K_PROP_NAME -- destination history embedding length k (default value 1)
        • L_PROP_NAME -- embedding length for the source past history vector (default value 1)
        • TIMESORTED_PROP_NAME -- whether each series of time stamps of spikes is sorted into temporal order. (default "true")

        Note: further properties may be defined by child classes.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if there is a problem with the supplied value, or if the property is recognised but unsupported (eg some calculators do not support all of the embedding properties).

      • getProperty

        java.lang.String getProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName)
                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Get current property values for the calculator.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, are the same as those for setProperty(String, String)

        Unknown property values are responded to with a null return value.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        Returns:
        current value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        void setObservations​(double[] source,
                     double[] destination)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single set of spiking observations from which to compute the PDF for transfer entropy. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.
        Parameters:
        source - series of time stamps of spikes for the source variable.
        destination - series of time stamps of spikes for the destination variable. Length will generally be different to the source, unlike other transfer entropy implementations, e.g. for TransferEntropyCalculator. source and destination must have the same reference time point, and each array is assumed to be sorted into temporal order unless the property TIMESORTED_PROP_NAME has been set to false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to addObservations(double[], double[]) rather than setObservations(double[], double[]) type methods (defined by the child interfaces and classes).

      • addObservations

        void addObservations​(double[] source,
                     double[] destination)
              throws java.lang.Exception

        Adds a new set of spiking observations to update the PDFs with. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after startAddObservations(). Call finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append or overlay these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them as independent trials - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Parameters:
        source - series of time stamps of spikes for the source variable. Will be returned in ascending sorted order.
        destination - series of time stamps of spikes for the destination variable. Length will generally be different to the source, unlike other transfer entropy implementations, e.g. for TransferEntropyCalculator. source and destination must have the same reference time point, and each array is assumed to be sorted into temporal order unless the property TIMESORTED_PROP_NAME has been set to false. Will be returned in ascending sorted order.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • finaliseAddObservations

        void finaliseAddObservations()
                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added via addObservations(double[], double[]), PDFs can now be constructed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet

        boolean getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet()
        Query whether the user has added more than a single observation set via the startAddObservations(), "addObservations" (defined by child interfaces and classes), finaliseAddObservations() sequence.
        Returns:
        true if more than a single observation set was supplied
